author: lovegrovegeorge
title: Catalyst Site: Education resources
description: The educational resources, links and calendar dates for Catalyst are scattered and don't have a friendly user interface.

assessments.note: Catalyst could indeed benefit from a dashboard page. One star less because the proposal does not elaborate how and by whom such a website will be maintained and what the ongoing costs are.

Providing comprehensive documentation can reduce the friction and confusion with onboarding new members. If the site is just one more link in the pile, it can make it difficult for new members to know that it is the correct one to use. Additional steps may be necessary to direct new users early on - like when installing Daedalus or Yoroi.

I think this is one of the main problems for Catalyst to start having a lot of engaged users. It is all a bit messy, different sources of information, and it is difficult to know what is going on when with different funds. The process is a little complicated, and we need a single page with all necessary information to know how we can get involved. If you are new, or haven't been on here in a few weeks it is very easy to be a bit confused about what is actually going on and how you can actually do things to help the whole community.
I quite like your idea and its not an overly complicated task. There is certainly a need for a calendar that highlights all dates but I do think it would need constant updating as dates will change.

The problem and description make sense, are clear and within the scope of the challenge. The organization of informations/dates would assist voters, CAs and vCAs in the search for relevant information. Although I believe that the proposal is more in line with the Distributed Decision Making challenge, I also see the relationship with this challenge.

This proposal does identifies a potential problem that may be frightening to the newcomers and may undermine the potential growth of the Catalyst Project, which is the overwhelming of information and the non-intuitive platform of the project. 
However, what may enrich the proposal is to be more far reaching. When we talk about a website simplifying the information it means that we are reaching people which are already interest to this project and want to participate already – because we can assume that they're allocating part of their time to read and understand and finally reaching the platform. However, to be fair, they're already a bit interested – and of course if they find a platform supplying with good information and intuitive navigation it'll help to aggregate them in the Project. But maybe if this platform includes more general information and educational (in a easy way) contents (starting from the beginning – decentralization, crypto potential, crypto intention, difference between the ecosystems, etc) and then present the Cardano and the Catalyst Project, I think it would have a greater strength to aggregate not only the people who are already looking and already know about it, but it could get newcomers into this world.
simplification of calendar and resources would be useful, though it may not directly affect the fund goal.

I believe the idea is very good, we really need a centralized website to gather most of the information around Catalyst. As mentioned in the proposal, there is already a website going on, and it would be good to partner up with them instead of doing something from scratch. I see that there are other developments going in the some website and it would be good to have it done like that. I was just a bit worried about the maintenance, since budget only mentions the setup, but I believe this will be included in a future proposal.

This project does have a significant impact on the catalyst community to create a calendar as well as learning resources that are stored on the catalyst.  This will be able to help grow awareness and centralize information needed to learn and understand Catalyst better than the current form of mixed social media items (Discord, Telegram, Catalyst Site, etc...).  Centralizing the resources in a single place will be helpful.  Further defining what those resources are and whether they are existing in another place or will be newly created.
Creating a website is not rocket science, so I have high confidence in that part. However, nothing was said about maintenance and keeping it up to date.
Aggregating the information is reasonable. The developer has the experience and is already using the proposed toolset as part of the proposal.

This seems like it should be simple enough to make a solution that is better than what we have now, in a relatively short amount of time. But people also need to know about it, so it should be connected to ideascale.

Given the experience stated, the plan provided and the resource links viewed I am confident that this team could deliver on this proposal. My one query might be in relation to synchronisation with the IOG team(s).

From what was described in the proposal, the only technical complexity would be the development of the website, which requires a developer, the rest of the proposal requires involvement, research and understanding of Catalyst. The experience described by the team indicates the ability to perform the task. I recommend including links so that the community has access to more information about Jakob and Ben, so that the community can check their qualifications transparently. Recalling that the team has a proposal in this same challenge that deals with the creation of a webpage with details about the teams, so the members themselves are well aware of the importance of having details of the proposers and even so they forgot to include this information. It is important to note that the project is already under development and the team is already adding information about the updates, which shows commitment.

There is a confusing aspect to the plan, the creation of a calendar, information and documentation will require constant updating and the budget describes funding for only 3 weeks of work. How will be the update of this information? This is not clear. There is a mention that in the long run more information will be added, but would that involve more funding?

The point is that to understand the feasibility of the budget, there must be clear deliverables, if the budget is only intended to create a calendar and aggregate information (something that is subjective and unclear in the proposal description) I believe that budget is unreasonable and above what is necessary.

In any case, it is not possible to be sure because the deliverables are not clear and there is no clarity as to whether the updates are included in the budget.

Although creating a web platform is not the hardest thing, what came to my attention is that only one participant gave its linkedin reference. We do not have relevant reference of the information of the other two which are already participating.
Another point is that the aim of this project is to 'merge with […] other relevant projects as possible […]" in order to be collaborative, but it does not explain how it wants to achieve it.
This proposal does not address how much money it'll need to start running and nor how much it would cost to maintenance and which part (how much or percentage) would stay in the pool.
I think it's important to have more clarity in the explanation of how it would be feasible – important to describe how much money it would cost to start, how it would generate funds to maintain the platform, how much would be necessary to stay in the pool, in accordance with the number of users, to incentive them to help the platform and how it would be delivered to them.

The proposers have a plan and budget to do this now, but it is not clear how this will work going forward. new calendar events and resources will continuously be added. how is this going to be managed? If it is maintained going forward it is not useful.

The team seems to have enough experience to put everything in place, and the proposed developments doesn't seem to be very difficult to implement. Budget for implementation makes sense, but some budget for maintenance should also be considered. Team is already committed and is working independently of the funding, which is very good.

This proposal is already in the works through the project team and additional funding will help accelerate and improve the existing work already done.  Project updates are all captured on the site notion.so and the roadmap has some structure to it.  Further defining the roadmap will make the future features clearer and help show priority in the work.  The budget breakdown is reasonable considering the two primary things that the project team has highlighted.  It would be nice to list some stretch goals since this is already in motion and what the additional funding may help get over the line.

What's missing are the dependencies. This is just one of several proposals totalling $35'200. 
The scope of this one includes just a calendar page and a list of links, which doesn't look overly ambitious. However, there is also the point "Ongoing collaboration with all content creators, community members and developers to integrate any of their current or planned education resources" which seems not to be budgeted

The proposal indicates the volume of traffic on the site would be a metric, and given tracking use on the site this can be done. There was also mention of reduced volume of requests in the other channels - which may be harder to evaluate as they may not be currently measured.  In addition, while the budgetary documentation indicated that the funds would be used to pay for AWS hosting; it did not indicate for how long or what the plan would be when those funds ran out.

This is both feasible and addresses the challenge effectively. People need clear information to understand how and when they can get involved. The impact per Ada spent on this could be great for Catalyst.
The proposal is well written and provides sufficient information to make an assessment. based on the size of the proposal and budget requested it seems a feasible prospect.

The problem, the solution and the proposal are aligned with the challenge.

The roadmap has no details, but it is objective, the timeline for the implementation is defined in 3 weeks, within the challenge requirements.

The project is already in development, some updates in the development have been added and can be checked and the team aims to add updates about the development on the website.

There is a budget breakdown, but as I mentioned in the rationale above, there is no clarity if updates to the calendar and information are included in the budget.

There are details about the proposers' experience. Reasonable metrics have been described, but there are no KPIs.

Although the objectives on the roadmap are clear, I miss a clearer date guided information. All the content is feasible in approximately in 3 weeks, but it does not comprehend a start or end date, nor how much time in each step. It would be easier to understand if it was more explained.
Nevertheless, I think that the success metrics list could be more compliant with the challenge objective.
When we put "qualitative feedback" on the use of the platform, we have a metric about the platform and not about how the platform engaged people to commit with the Catalyst Project. 
Maybe a good way to measure if the people using the platform are committing with the Catalyst Project and if the platform is bringing new people to the project is to add a little survey before and after each fund, which elucidate to the platform if the person who is using the platform is new to the project, if (s)he engaged in it, if the platform helped him to understand and embracing the project, etc.

Since this a simple project, I see that the a delivery date is all that's needed to audit the development and the information is there in the text. The success metrics are not that clear and seem to be a little hard to properly measure, like qualitative feedback and relation between people who need support and people looking for support. Number of viewers, as mentioned, might be a better way to track the usage, if people are coming back it's because it's relevant. Budget breakdown is good and well explained.

The team has a rough roadmap in place and project updates captured, but an additional place to state target milestones/deliverables would help create additional auditability metrics.   Basic KPIs/Metrics would help to measure the velocity and completion of the project as well.

solution: Create a user friendly calendar page and aggregated resources for learning about Catalyst.
experience:
5+ years of web and mobile development experience

1 year of strategic consulting (external & inhouse) experience
